author: paul spinrad
text: __ fetish ____ inner light __look past the psion 5mx's shiny clamshell and sliding-unfold keyboard to see the elegance within: the epoc operating system, less than half the size of microsoft's niche-plugging wince. the 5mx does everything a pda should, with easy pc syncing via serial port or infrared, and when you pair it with a gsm phone it handles email, faxes, and web sites. external buttons run the voice recorder when the unit is closed and powered off. with third-party software, the touchscreen even recognizes handwriting. most tellingly, sclerotic wince handhelds typically conk out 10 hours after a full charge. the psion runs for 50. 5mx: $549. psion computer: +1 (978) 371 0310, www.psion.com.__ deep voice __water may be radio-opaque, but that shouldn't spoil the party. the buddy phone transmits voice through the ocean as ultrasound - just like whale songs, but at dog-whistle frequencies. push the talk button, as on a walkie-talkie, and your diving partners hear you from 50 to 500 meters away, depending on conditions; one 9-volt battery runs the transceiver for about 20 hours. the buddy phone is the first sport diving version of the aquacom systems used to make the upcoming james bond movie, but you don't need an appointment with q to get it. buddy phone xt-100: $410. ocean technology systems: +1 (714) 754 7848, www.oceantechnologysystems.com.__ button down __you're sick of wasting brain cells on the constant barrage of competing pricing plans. uniden's long distance manager cordless phone comparison-shops for you at the press of a button. hit long dst and you're connected to a carrier whose rates are dictated by callmanage's intelligent selection system. then you dial the number normally and you're guaranteed one of the lowest rates going for major carriers, with no additional surcharges, minimum times, or service fees. long distance manager exli8962: $89.95. uniden america: +1 (817) 858 3300, www.uniden.com.__ sporting wood __there's a time and place for titanium, but why not cruise the strand on a hand-carved, tropical-hardwood chick magnet? javanese woodcarvers handcraft the uprider from durable teak, securing all joints with pegs, not screws. the only metal you'll find is in the wheels, brakes, and drivetrain. you can order the 60-pound work of ridable art with extras like an 18-speed derailleur or a bull's head on the handlebars, to complete the tiki lowrider look. but supplies are limited - the indonesian government controls the teak harvest, and skilled carvers don't grow on trees. uprider: $2,500. the amazing wooden bike company: +44 (181) 542 2920, www.candytape.com/awbc.__ axis power __turning stereo design on its ear, kenwood outfitted its axis shelf system with gravity sensors and autoadjusting lcd panels. flip the components on their sides and the displays turn right-side up. cds, cassettes, and minidiscs load and play perfectly with the players flat or en pointe. besides knowing what's up, the fit-anywhere cd receiver can read the high-definition compatible digital (hdcd) information encoded on some newer discs. the minidisc deck simplifies digital recording with quick-edit features. so what about your lps? no luck; a tiltable, vertical-playing turntable might be tough. axis (full system): $1,300. kenwood: +1 (310) 639 9000, www.kenwoodusa.com.__ space mouse __let's be honest: the average mouse lacks depth, living in a two-dimensional world, with its little arrow cursor always pointing to 11 o'clock, knowing no other way. this is fine for standard apps, but woefully weak for virtual reality, which demands a more realistic range of motion. spacecat tracks all possible moves - rotation as well as simple movement, in and out as well as on the plane. the four-programmable-button joymouse connects via serial port and transmits movements and clicks at 9,600 baud. give your flatland gymnastics a rest and start manipulating vr objects like a human being. spacecat: $1,000. smart device: +41 (1) 253 2357, www.smart-device.com.__ jet t'aime __model airplanes have entered the jet age. the 86-inch rafale b 01, powered by twin ram750 microjets, cruises at 225 mph plus, so you need a lot of space to fly it. the engines, which produce 18 pounds of thrust apiece at 115,000 rpm, are earplug loud. and the kit promotes instant gratification for the speed need, with easy-assembling prefab components of carbon fiber, epoxy, and steel. for quiet, old-fashioned model-making satisfaction, try building a ship-in-a-bottle. rafale b 01: $7,992. bob violett models: +1 (407) 327 6333, www.bvmjets.com.__ voicemailbox __somebody had to do it: give small businesses the same voicemail capabilities as allied megacorp's centrex. bizfon handles six incoming lines and eight phones, with mailboxes for each, plus two announcement boxes (for directions to the party), and a directory of extensions. you can transfer, autoforward, and conference-call, and anything you can do from the office, you can do remotely. best, the standard audio input lets you connect a cd player for custom hold music. metal? bacharach? hey, it's your system. bizfon 680: $1,295. bizfon: +1 (603) 870 9400, www.bizfon.com.__ inflationary times __with the airpro, a high-profile watch for the young sportswear crowd, seiko has decided to run screaming from its staid, jewelry-store image. two conspicuous air-pump and release-valve buttons adjust the pressurized band to conform perfectly to your wrist, supplying a functional excuse for design overkill. all watches in the airpro line, like the smc-003 shown here, resist water to 100 meters and include standard sports-chronograph features like a stopwatch, calendar, and alarm. sls models, the fanciest, have dot-matrix screens that display times and calling codes for 38 international cities. airpro smc-003: $215. seiko: +1 (201) 529 5730, www.seikousa.com.
